Name: Schleswig-Holstein
Fate: Sunk by bombs 1944; scuttled 21 March 1945; raised and beached for long-term use as target 1948; remains still extant.
Displacement:
Normal: 13,191 t (12,983 long tons)
Full load: 14,218 t (13,993 long tons)
Armament:
At construction:

2 × 2 – 28 cm (11 in) SK L/40 guns
14 × 17 cm (6.7 in) SK L/40 guns
22 × 8.8 cm (3.5 in) SK L/45 guns
6 × 45 cm (17.7 in) torpedo tubes

Armament in 1926:

2 × 2 – 28 cm SK L/40 guns
12 × 15 cm SK L/45 guns
8 × 8.8 cm SK L/45 guns
4 × 50 cm (19.7 in) torpedo tubes

Armament in 1939:

2 × 2 – 28 cm SK L/40 guns
10 × 15 cm SK L/45 guns
4 × 8.8 cm SK L/45 anti-aircraft guns
4 × 3.7 cm (1.5 in) guns
Armor:
Belt: 240 mm (9.4 in)
Turrets: 280 mm (11 in)
Deck: 40 mm (1.6 in)
Commanders:
Gustav Kieseritzky
Walter Hennecke
Gustav Kleikamp
